I agree that there might be a little (understatement) too much money spent on the military. I won't try using the military version of the dumb elephant joke to justify it ("Why are you painting that elephant's toenails red?" "So it can hide in the roses." "I've never seen an elephant in the roses." "See? It must work!"). However, the military has provided us with many civilian uses of technology and has been a major player in many of our technological breakthroughs (like the space race, GPS satellites, JEEPS, Hummers, etc, etc). While 40 billion is a bit absurd, I do agree that money does not always make things better. Let me use an analogy.
 
 Say the extra money does go to the schools and we buy computers and better textbooks for every child. We repair the buildings and get better playground equipment. However, none of these things help a kid gain a significant advantage if they do not take the initiative and work to better their place in society. Carnegie (the steel millionaire of the late 19th century) started as a poor boy who worked hellish shifts in a factory. In his free time, he could not go to school because of his poverty and long work days. Instead, he went to the public library and read up on topics. Through his private initiative, which costed no money whatsoever, he was able to recognize an opportunity when he saw it and became the captain of industry that we learn about today.
 
 As for the other nations, they don't have our GNP and so cannot hope to match us in a spending war (that's what drove the Soviets to ruin).
